awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Finding the Double Sunsets - Stellar Multiplicity Across the Milky Way Halo
awd_abstract_narration:
Unlike our own Sun, many stars in the Milky Way have one or more companions.  Not only do these multiple star systems make for the pretty double sunsets like that seen by Luke Skywalker in the film "Star Wars", they also help astronomers to learn how stars form from gas clouds.  These stars change with time and affect their surroundings.  Yet astronomers' understanding of stellar "multiplicity" is limited to just a few basic properties, like the fraction of stars that have companions within the Milky Way.  The investigators will use already available data from two extensive astronomical surveys to learn much more about multiple star systems.  The investigators will learn how the stellar sizes and masses depend on their ages, chemical composition and galactic environment. 

The investigators will develop a new statistical technique to glean this information from as few as 3-5 observations per star.  The different data sets will span the entire Milky Way, from its disk to its halo and also to dwarf galaxy satellites.  The program will be the first of its kind to learn the details of multiple star systems in so many different environments.

The investigators will host workshops, aimed at middle- and high-school educators from local schools, to share the experience of research using on-line tools.   Their efforts will enhance an educator-focused resource for teaching topics in mathematics, physics and computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The importance of binary star systems to astrophysics is difficult to overstate.  Not only do binaries provide a foundation for measuring masses of individual stars, they also serve as sources of some of the most intensely-studied phenomena---e.g., novae and supernova explosions, and gravitational waves.  Yet a comprehensive understanding of the formation and evolution of binary systems remains elusive.  Ultimately, we require knowledge of the statistics of stellar multiplicity---the fraction of star systems that contain bound stellar companions, and the various parameters that describe their orbits: period, eccentricity, masses of the two partners.  

These quantities are well measured only within the Milky Way.  In order to understand stellar multiplicity more generally, we must study its behavior in different stellar environments, especially those at old age and with relatively few heavy metals.  In this project, we focus on precisely this regime, studying the properties of binary stars within the Milky Way’s ‘dwarf’ galaxy satellites.  These systems comprise the smallest, oldest, and most chemically primitive stellar populations known, offering the best opportunity to detect variations in stellar multiplicity across different environments.  

Our project is designed specifically to overcome limitations imposed by the fact that a binary star system within a dwarf galaxy is not observed directly as two distinct sources, but instead must be inferred based on observed changes in the velocity measured (via spectroscopy) of what appears as a single unresolved point source.  Specifically, the problem we confront is: given a sample containing a handful of velocity measurements for each of a few hundred stars in a given dwarf galaxy, how can we infer not only the orbital properties of individual binary systems, but also the properties — binary fraction, mean period, etc. — that characterize the entire population of binary systems?  It turns out that this information is crucial not only for understanding binary stars themselves, but also for our ability to use the observed stellar velocities to infer the masses and dark matter content of the dwarf galaxies.  

For this project we have developed novel methodology that operates in two stages.  In the first, we analyze every star individually, fitting binary orbits (by varying parameters like the orbital period, eccentricity, mass ratio, orbital inclination, etc.) to the velocities measured at different times.  Then, in a second step, we combine all of these results under what is now a ‘hierarchical’ model, where we vary parameters (mean period, binary fraction, etc.) that characterize the population of binary stars.  This marks the first time that such a hierarchical model has been applied to this problem, and much of our effort has been devoted to testing its efficacy by applying to mock data to see if we could recover the known input parameters that were used to generate the data.  These tests allowed us to fine-tune our methodology, tailoring the tradeoff between precision and accuracy to suit the quality of available data.  

After developing and validating our methodology, thus far we have applied it to real data sets for two dwarf galaxies.  We fit binary orbits to all stars in the Triangulum II dwarf galaxy that have multiple velocity measurements, inferring the orbital properties of a previously-detected binary star system and showing that a proper accounting for this system’s motion reduces the mass inferred for Triangulum II.  We apply the full hierarchical analysis to the Sextans dwarf galaxy, obtaining the first inferences about the binary population (distribution of periods, etc.) within a dwarf galaxy.  We find that the Sextans population has a shorter mean period, and a smaller range of periods, than is inferred for stars in the Milky Way, suggesting that stellar multiplicity indeed depends environment.  

Broader Impacts: The PI wrote a publicly-available software package for generating mock stellar data sets of the kind used to test methodology in this project.  The package generates samples of stellar positions and masses drawn from a variety of well-known (user-specified) analytic functions, and allows for the insertion of synthetic binary star populations with specified distributions of orbital properties.  The package also serves as a teaching tool, generating animations of binary orbits in position and velocity space as functions of time, for arbitrary input parameters.  

The PI also engaged in various community outreach activities, including public lectures in Pittsburgh-area public schools and adult-learning programs, as well as serving as an instructor in Carnegie Mellon University’s Summer Academy for Math and Science, a six-week residential program in which high school students from under-represented minority groups learn about STEM-related fields in a University setting.
